input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

if you're thinking about leading a more active lifestyle you're not alone in recent years an increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports fitness and recreation whether you're trying to get fit build muscle or you're just tired of the couch here are some changes you can expect along the way during that first workout you might feel more alert and energized because ramping up your heart rate means a boost in overall blood flow and oxygen to the brain but prepare yourself for the day after when you'll almost certainly get a case of Dom's short for delayed onset muscle soreness the soreness will persist for about 72 hours but the good news is you're less likely to get it again as long as you continue to regularly exercise those same muscles over the next few weeks you'll slowly start to ramp up production of mitochondria via a process called mitochondrial biogenesis mitochondria are the parts of your cells that convert carbs fat and protein and to feel that your muscles use to do their job like flexing contract after six to eight weeks studies have shown that people can increase their mitochondria by up to 50% with more mitochondria in your cells you'll start to feel more fit and your endurance will increase so running three miles will no longer feel as difficult as it did during the first week once your six months in all of that hard work should finally start to show if your workouts focus on strength training you'll notice your muscles begin to take shape you're also less likely to fall off the workout wagon at this point exercise programs often see a 50% dropout rate within the first six months but after that more people stick with it now if you're more focused on cardio than by nine months of regular exercise you should see about a 25% increase in your vo2 max vo2 max is often used as a measure of fitness and refers to the rate your body can transport oxygen to your muscles for fuel basically higher vo2 max means you can run faster for longer so a 25% increase means you can run about 20% further in the same amount of time after one year of regular exercise your bones will be denser which reduces your of osteoporosis in fact researchers have found that regular resistance training when combined with aerobic exercise can actually reverse the effects of osteoporosis after 12 months now if you maintain your exercise program long term your body might not be the only thing to benefit your bank account may also be one study revealed that older people who exercise 5 days a week for at least 30 minutes saved on average $2,500 a year in medical costs for heart related health problems alone you'll also be at a lower risk of developing arthritis type-2 diabetes dementia and certain types of cancer like breast and colon in all probability you are going to live longer than you otherwise would and that longer life it will likely feel more fulfilling because exercise lowers the risk of anxiety and depression by reducing levels of stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline of course all of these benefits depend on the type and intensity of your workout and how long you exercise for each week a balanced diet is also paramount to a healthy lifestyle for the average adult ages 18 to 64 the US Department of Health and Human Services recommends either a minimum of two and a half hours per week of moderately intense exercise like brisk walking or biking or at least one hour and 15 minutes each week that combines moderate and high intensity workouts like running and swimming sprints on top of that make sure and take two days each week to strengthen your muscles with some weights or resistance training this will help your overall speed and endurance as you begin it's important to pace yourself and not push too hard too fast or you risk serious injury you'll discover that the fitter you become the easier it will be to exert a little more energy the next week the week after and so forth exercise smart and often and you'll be running marathons in no time you

claims.text: An increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports, fitness, and recreation in recent years.
During the first workout, you might feel more alert and energized due to increased blood flow and oxygen to the brain.
Delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) will persist for about 72 hours after a workout.
Regular exercise can ramp up production of mitochondria via mitochondrial biogenesis.
Studies have shown that people can increase their mitochondria by up to 50% after six to eight weeks of exercise.
After six months of exercise, people are less likely to drop out of their workout programs, which often see a 50% dropout rate in the first six months.
After nine months of regular exercise, you should see about a 25% increase in your VO2 max.
After one year of regular exercise, your bones will be denser, reducing your risk of osteoporosis.
Regular resistance training combined with aerobic exercise can reverse the effects of osteoporosis after 12 months.
Older people who exercise 5 days a week for at least 30 minutes save on average $2,500 a year in medical costs for heart-related health problems.
Regular exercise lowers the risk of anxiety and depression by reducing levels of stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline.
The US Department of Health and Human Services recommends a minimum of 2.5 hours of moderately intense exercise per week for adults aged 18 to 64.

input_prompt:
Claim: An increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports, fitness, and recreation in recent years.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
REFUTES (1 sources):
  1. SFIA | 2023 U.S. Trends in Team Sports Report | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://sfia.org/resources/team-sport-participation-recovered-to-pre-pandemic-levels-last-year/
     Summary: The SFIA report indicates that the total number of participants in team sports in the U.S. was 70.8 million in 2022, suggesting a stable level of participation rather than an increase in recent years.
SUPPORTS (3 sources):
  1. [PDF] 2023 OUTDOOR PARTICIPATION TRENDS REPORT | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://outdoorrecreation.wi.gov/Documents/Research%20Library%20Page%20files/US%20-%20Demographics%20%26%20Participation/2023_OutdoorFoundation_Participation_Report.pdf
     Summary: The evidence indicates that outdoor recreation participation in the U.S. increased by 2.3% in 2022, reaching a record 168.1 million participants, which supports the claim that more Americans are engaging in sports, fitness, and recreation activities.
  2. SFIA Study: Record growth continues in 2023 for U.S. sports and ... | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/05/30/sports-fitness-industry-association-survey/
     Summary: The evidence indicates that in 2023, the number of active sports and fitness participants in the U.S. reached a record high of 242 million, representing a 12.1% increase from the previous year, which supports the claim of increased participation in sports and fitness.
  3. A Record Number of Americans Participated in Sports, Fitness ... | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.sportsdestinations.com/sports/all-sports/record-number-americans-participated-sports-33929
     Summary: The evidence indicates that the number of Americans participating in sports and fitness activities has consistently increased over the past decade, with a notable growth of 5 million participants in 2023 alone.
UNCLEAR (2 sources):
  1. Americans engaged in leisure/sports US 2023 - Statista | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.statista.com/statistics/189548/daily-engagement-of-the-us-population-in-leisure-and-sports/?srsltid=AfmBOooShjN7wlyOqtrnDoDDqna3onqiUt5KbjJgPGWGhgTB10ZftG-7
     Summary: Approximately 95.5 percent of men were engaged in sport and leisure activities that year, and that figure was 92.7 percent for women.
  2. Ready to Play: Sports and fitness participation grows steadily | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/06/03/sports-participation/
     Summary: “We went from just under 73% of Americans participating in one of the 200-plus activities that we monitor in 2018 to 78.8% in 2023,” said SFIA ...

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding participation in sports, fitness, and recreation among Americans. While the SFIA report indicates stable participation in team sports at 70.8 million in 2022, other sources, such as the Outdoor Participation Trends Report and the SFIA study, show significant increases in outdoor recreation and overall sports participation, with 242 million active participants in 2023, marking a 12.1% increase. Additionally, Statista and another SFIA report suggest a steady growth in overall participation rates, indicating that while team sports may not be increasing, broader engagement in sports and fitness activities is on the rise.

context.claim_text: An increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports, fitness, and recreation in recent years.
context.query_text: more Americans engaging in sports and recreation activities trends 2020 2023
